title.narrative: Socio economic impact analysis of COVID-19

description.narrative: The COVID-19 pandemic will have numerous immediate and long-term impacts on the Lao economy, including declines in domestic dem business travel, trade and production linkages, and supply chain disruptions. With tourism accounting for 13% of Lao economy, the impa been felt heavily as the number of tourists is declining under current restrictions, which then has spillover effects on tourism-related transport, aviation, resorts, hotels and restaurants and their supply chains. Large scale construction projects which rely on materials a China are likely to experience delays setting off poor demand

description.narrative: Se adquieren equipos de ultrasonidos para fortalecer la capacidad de diganóstico del sistema de salud y garantizar la contención de la pandemia COVID-19
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

description.narrative: 1- Number of national and local institutions with infraestructure and operational capacities strengthened to assure their efficient and effective performance in the face of COVID-19 2- Number of new audiovisual and printed promotional material produced

comment.narrative: 1. 5 instituciones nacionales y locales fortalecidas 2. 4 productos comunicativos realizados

1. Se fortalecieron 5 instituciones nacionales: Los hospitales clínico-quirúrgicos Miguel Enríquez, en La Habana y los hospitales provinciales clínico-quirúrgicos Arnaldo Milián Castro, en Villa Clara y Saturnino Lora, en Santiago de Cuba. La Sala Situacional del EMNDC y Prosalud. Se adquirieron 3 equipos de ultrasonido o ecógrafos para vigilancia y diagnóstico de pacientes con comorbilidades y sospechosos de COVID. Se ubicaron en hospitales clínicos-quirúrgicos de La Habana, Villa Cara y Santiago de Cuba. Estos resultados y los gastos asociados a ellos, se complementaron con los fondos RRF de PNUD. En la Sala Situacional en interés de la toma de decisiones del EMNDC, fortalecida con equipamiento informático, se logró un mejor flujo de información a partir de las comunicaciones y equipos informáticos proporcionados. Se mejoró la visualización de sitios y plataformas satelitales a través de la conexión inalámbrica, mejoraron los niveles de audio. Esto permitió un mejor enlace con todas las instancias de la estructura de la Defensa Civil en Cuba, permitiendo la toma de decisiones oportuna y la transmisión de información al Centro de Dirección del Estado Mayor Nacional de la Defensa Civil y al Consejo de Defensa Nacional. Se proporcionaron medios de protección personal (EPP) y suministros en apoyo a la ampliación de las capacidades de admisión hospitalaria que garantizó la vitalidad de los servicios y el apoyo al personal clave del MINSAP y de la Defensa Civil, consistentes en: 40,000 guantes, 7,000 bolsas para desechos biológicos, 950 batas quirúrgicas, 8,352 mascarillas N-95 y 20,000 mascarillas IIR. Estos artículos fueron destinados al Instituto de Medicina Tropical Pedro Kouri-IPK y para 5 Laboratorios de Diagnóstico de hospitales La Habana y para el Laboratorio de la Defensa Civil. Estos resultados y los gastos asociados a ellos, se complementaron con los fondos RRF de PNUD. Se beneficiaron 41,000 trabajadores de Salud Pública. 2. Se ampliaron las capacidades para implementar campañas de capacitación y sensibilización con perspectiva de género, alineadas con la campaña nacional del MINSAP de prevención y reducción del riesgo de contagio por COVID-19, con la realización de spot publicitarios. Estos resultados y los gastos asociados a ellos, se complementaron con los fondos RRF de PNUD, hasta completar y superar el indicador de 10 productos comunicativos.
N/D
N/D

Strengthening the integrated system of reaching out to the most vulnerable groups, by upgrading and digitalizing the social services information system and by expanding the capacity of social workers
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

description.narrative: • Number of new information fields became available for the social workers about target groups • Number of information system integrated into the information system being developed for social workers • Time and effort to spent to get collect all available information about a certain citizen or household • Average time and effort spent to process a typical case • The average time and difficulty level to get a complaint resolved (from the citizen’s point of view)

comment.narrative: • Due to insufficient citizen profiling, the government is incapable to channel the rapid response to the target group precisely. At the moment, the government can only increase the amount of welfare for selected existing programs rather than designing a new, customized program within a short time. • Social workers’ outreach is limited and it is partly due to the lack of a system that enables more efficient, organized, and integrated workflow. • The social services provided by different agencies are not well-orchestrated, at the grass-root level. As a result, social workers’ workload is increased and the overall quality of their work is compromised.

• Hire consultants and conduct an analysis of the existing system, identify areas for improvement • Design information system that enhances social workers’ ability to access citizen data from multi-sources • Conduct procurement of key services and award a contract

• Hired consultants and performed a complete analysis of the existing system, identified areas for improvement • In consultation with MLSP, the gov’t partner body designed the social worker’s information system • Some procurements are delayed due to unforeseen circumstances

• Develop and pilot the social worker’s information system • Once completed transferring the system to the Ministry of Labor and Social Protection • Rollout the system nationwide • Create online training modules for the social workers on the chosen topics

comment.narrative: The 2017 Service Availability and Readiness Assessment for Libya, conducted by WHO and MOH, found that only 4 of 97 hospitals are functional at a level of 75-80% of its capacity; 17% of hospitals (17 out of 97) and 20% of primary health care centres (273 out of 1,355) are closed, and the rest are not well ready for service delivery. GHSI, March 2020

description.narrative:
No. of recovery plans developed
No. of socio-economic impact analysis coducted

comment.narrative: Multi-topic household survey

1. Conduct UN-Wide Social and Economic Impact Analysis 2. Develop Private Sector Recovery Plan 3. Develop Informal Sector Recovery Plan 4. Develop Social Protection Recovery Plan 5. Develop business Continuity Plan for SDP

Under the Socio-Economic Impact and Recovery output, UNDP led the UN-wide Social and Economic Impact Analysis, with ILO, UNICEF, UNFPA, WHO, WB, UNDP, RCO and the UK High Commission. This analysis unpacked the impact of the pandemic across the 5 UN pillars: health first, protecting people, economic recovery, macroeconomic response, and social cohesion and. Based on this, UNDP developed three recovery plans underpinned by the principle of Building Back Better: i) A Private Sector Recovery Plan has been developed for the national private sector network Business Botswana together with ILO and the World Bank. This plan analyses the impact on the private sector and sets out a plan of action in which the private sector takes the lead and initiative to build back better. The plan places a particular focus on digital transformation, green economy, opportunities in the health sector and supporting women and youth-led businesses; ii) ii) An Informal Sector Recovery Plan for the Ministry of Investment Trade and Industry together with ILO and the WB. This plan provided an in-depth analysis of informal sector concepts, definitions, and the multi-faceted impacts of the pandemic. Based on this, clear recommendations and actions were proposed to establish support structures at national and regional levels, whilst also accelerating recovery actions leveraging digital solutions, revitalizing local value chains and marketplaces and building capacities of informal sector participants; and iii) iii) a Social Protection Recovery Plan for the Ministry of Local Government and Rural Development together with UNICEF, ILO, FAO, UNFPA, RCO and WB. This plan evaluated the impact of the pandemic, particularly for the most vulnerable groups. It further reviewed how the current systems responded, and based on this, presented recommendations for how the social protection system could be strengthened. Private Sector & SMEs: Through the Supplier Development Programme, UNDP supported 44 SMEs and 7 large companies with a business continuity planthat facilitated supply chain continuity, access to funding and the diversification of products and markets. All the businesses stayed in business and are now scaling up. Further, UNDP supported 110 entrepreneurs of the national Poverty Eradication programme with PPEs to continue their operations.
the project ended in December 2020
the project ended in December 2020

capital of a political entity
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: 1.1.1.a: Number of village representatives equipped to channel local needs to municipal centers 1.1.1.b: Number of municipal shelters properly equipped for needs of elderly and homeless 1.1.1.c: Number of front-line public-sector workers throughout the country equipped with PPEs 1.1.1.d: Percentage increase in the daily response rate of the 144 emergency call center 1.2.1.a: Number of people reached/engaged throughout the country through COVID-19 public awareness and risk communication activities, broken down by gender and target audiences (general population; the elderly; children/youth/parents; national minorities, persons with disabilities and other marginalized groups). 1.2.1b: Number of farm households benefiting from provision of seeds and other agricultural inputs by UNDP, including in Abkhazia, Georgia

comment.narrative: 1.1.1.a:126 village representatives equipped to channel local needs to municipal centers 1.1.1.b: At least 3 municipal shelters properly equipped for needs of elderly and homeless 1.1.1.c: 9,000 (60% of whom women) front-line public-sector workers throughout the country equipped with PPEs 1.1.1.d: At least 10 % increase in the daily response rate of the 144 emergency call center 1.2.1.a: tbd (Number of people reached/engaged throughout the country through COVID-19 public awareness and risk communication activities, broken down by gender and target audiences (general population; the elderly; children/youth/parents; national minorities, persons with disabilities and other marginalized groups). 1.2.1b: At least 300 farm households benefiting from provision of seeds and other agricultural inputs by UNDP, including in Abkhazia, Georgia

1.1.1.a: In progress: to implement the Project output 1.1.1 UNDP has announced a tender to purchase computers for village representatives and signed a PO contract with Multi Solutions Group (MSG) on 26 Oct 2020 at USD 60,984.00 in total. The company took responsibility to provide goods within 60 days. However, on 17 Nov, the company provided an explanation letter referring to the difficulties of suppliers on the global market as a result of the pandemic. Thus, the company said that it will only be able to deliver the goods by mid-February 2021. UNDP conducted an ad hoc market research, which revealed that other companies have the same problems due to the pandemic. Therefore, replacement of the provider was not undertaken, and the project deadline was extended until 31 March. 1.1.1.b: Completed: 3 shelters equipped housing 200 elderly and homeless. 1.1.1.c: Completed: more then 8000 civil servants at central and local levels equipped with PPEs (more then 60 % are women) 1.1.1.d: N/a Relevant data is requested and is awaited from AoG 1.2.1.a: Completed: 120 000 families reached directly through the print materials 1.2.1b: Completed: 480 vulnerable households engaged in small family farming in seven regions have received agricultural inputs. In Abkhazia, 4 agricultural grants were allocated to two women and two men, leading to the creation of 11 new jobs and reaching 60 direct beneficiaries or 15 farmers households.

description.narrative: The output aims to enhance inclusive and multi-sectoral crisis management and responses by ensuring a human rights-based approach to responding to COVID19 and protecting vulnerable groups as well as community engagement for social cohesion.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: - Organize seminars and workshops for government officials to help them implement their duties and fulfill the obligations as per national laws and international and regional instruments on human rights. - Cooperate with the OHCHR and an Egyptian ICT company to create a digital platform for monitoring the implementation of recommendations issued by international and regional treaty mechanisms for human rights - Support the development and implementation of the Supreme Standing Committee for Human Rights (SSCHR) media strategy.

comment.narrative: - No seminar and workshop on human rights organized for government officials - No monitoring platform for human rights exists - No sensitization/communication campaign to raise awareness on human rights implemented

- Develop conceptual framework of training courses on human-rights and knowledge products - Disseminate online training courses to Government Officers to help them implement their duties and meet the obligations imposed by the national and/or international laws and instruments - Support development of SSCHR communication strategy. - Design and implement sensitization/ communication campaigns to raise awareness on human rights within society, with priority given to vulnerable rights holders
- Project were not initiated due to the security clearance of the Government of Egypt

• Disseminate online training courses to Government Officers to help them implement their duties and meet the obligations imposed by the national and/or international laws and instruments • Support the Supreme Standing Committee on Human Rights, SSCHR, in developing the monitoring system on human rights issues • Support development of SSCHR communication strategy • Raise awareness on human rights within society, with priority given to vulnerable rights holders through designing and implementing communication activities. • Coordinate with line ministers (MoJ, HR departments of line ministries, etc.) to identify the need of training (needs assessment)

description.narrative: The UN COVID-19 Response and Recovery Multi-Partner Trust Fund (UN COVID-19 MPTF) for Immediate UN Response for coherent safeguarding the livelihoods of people made most vulnerable by COVID-19 in Nepal
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: Livelihood recovery through Covid-19 response activities

comment.narrative: zero
- Employment generation through entrepreneurship development (600)

· As a part of Generation of self- employment and job opportunities through entrepreneurship development, 600 enterprises are targeted to be supported to create jobs for 1000 vulnerable and marginalized population in Sudurpaschim and Karnali Province of Nepal. A rapid Entrepreneurship Development Training has already been conducted for more than 400 individuals ( 40 % women).
· Similarly as a part of Short-term employment support, 250 labor worker, porters including women workers in the tourism section who have lost their jobs are targeted as the beneficiaries for short term employment support in clearing and managing the waste in different trekking routes thereby supporting the workers in the Tourism sector most affected by the pandemic. This activity is being implemented in partnership with the Nepal Tourism Board (NTB). NTB has already coordinated with the respective five municipalities (local governments) in Province no. 1, Province no. 2 and Gandaki Province of Nepal and preparatory work are being done.

description.narrative: Strengthening the Quarantine & Isolation Capacity across the three Atolls in line with Tokelau COVID-19 Preparedness and Response Plan, and long term use
seat of a first-order administrative division

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: 1.1 Number of fully upgraded and refurbished quarantine & isolation centres that are operational 1.2 Number of rooms that are fully equipped with isolation capacities. 1.3 Number of rooms equipped with air conditioning and back up power supply

comment.narrative: 1.1 3 Fully Upgraded Quanratine & Isolation Centres across 3 Atolls 1.2 At least 60 rooms that are fully equipped and operational 1.3 At least 15 rooms equipped with airconditioning and back up power supply

1.1 Three (3) Quarantine Centres fully refurbished and operational on each Atoll (Fakaofo, Nukunonu, Atafu) with each Centres having the capacity to accommodate up to 30 people. Additional public structures have also been equipped to accommodate any influx of quarantine personnel 1.2. Sixty (60) Rooms/ Isolations Units have been fully upgraded and equipped with isolations capacities 1.3. Twenty One (21) Air Conditioning Units have been installed across the Centres across the 3 Atolls (Fakaofo, Nukunonu, Atafu)

Produit 1 : - Nombre de référentiel de sécurité sanitaire établi

Produit 1 : - L'étude pour la réalisation du référentiel de sécurité sanitaire a été lancée et le Bureau Veritas a pu produire les premiers livrables à savoir : l'élaboration du référentiel en arabe et en français et la conception d'une plateforme en ligne. Néanmoins la mission devrait s'étendre à 2021 à travers une extension sans-coûts.

Evidence-based platform on economic and social impact of the COVID 19 pandemic in Bahrain, established.
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: a. Number of national analyses of the economic and social impact of the COVID-19. b. Number of digital discussion platforms on socio and economic response. c. Number of UN Response Offer initiatives in support to the Government

comment.narrative: This project is aligned to the global UNDP COVID-19 Response, Policy and Programme Offer, as well as the recently submitted United Nations COVID-19 Response Offer to the Government of Bahrain (April 16th), which proposes 40 service offers from 18 UN entities, ranging from direct support, to monitoring, analysis, capacity development and awareness raising. The UN Response Offer was shared with the Government of Bahrain. UNDP’s main contributions to the Response Offer are in terms of PPE and medical equipment procurement, as well as contributing to a national socio-economic impact assessment. The latter would be conducted with contributions by the UN System, and in particular IOM, UNICEF, ILO, and, UNIDO.
Gap and swot analysis on existing national digital system. Digital transformation strategy developed
Government’s Digital Transformation Strategy supported, including improved health and communications
